message_1: A manufacturer of light bulbs wants to estimate the average lifetime of its bulbs. A sample of 50 light bulbs has a mean lifetime of 1200 hours and a standard deviation of 200 hours. Calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true mean lifetime of the light bulbs.
message_2:
To calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true mean lifetime of the light bulbs, we will use the following formula:

Confidence Interval = x̄ ± (Z * (σ / √n))

where:
x̄ = sample mean (1200 hours)
Z = Z-score for a 95% confidence interval (1.96)
σ = sample standard deviation (200 hours)
n = sample size (50 light bulbs)

First, we need to calculate the standard error (SE):

SE = σ / √n = 200 / √50 ≈ 28.28

Now, we can calculate the margin of error (ME):

ME = Z * SE = 1.96 * 28.28 ≈ 55.43

Finally, we can calculate the confidence interval:

Lower limit = x̄ - ME = 1200 - 55.43 ≈ 1144.57 hours
Upper limit = x̄ + ME = 1200 + 55.43 ≈ 1255.43 hours

So, the 95% confidence interval for the true mean lifetime of the light bulbs is approximately (1144.57 hours, 1255.43 hours).
